metadata.case_name: Defendants Nos. 1 and 2 v. Balkrishna Sitaram Sontakke

facts.text: Joint Hindu family of 6 brothers carried on joint family business of grocery shop, liquor shops, ration shop, motor-bus service and moneylending under the name of Sontakke Brothers. Family possessed immovable and movable property.
Balkrishna Sitaram Sontakke is the eldest brother and plaintiff respondent.
Up to 1944, brothers living and messing together; income from family business kept with plaintiff.
From April 14, 1945, parties began to appropriate proceeds of various businesses separately: plaintiff running liquor shops, defendants Nos. 1 and 2 motor-bus service, defendant No. 4 grocery shop.
Parties tried partition through arbitrators but failed.
On June 29, 1945, five brothers filed suit No. 39 of 1945 for partition against plaintiff of all joint family properties including accounts.

Suit compromised on March 7, 1946: prior to 1942 accounts correctly maintained; arbitrators for accounts 1942 to March 31, 1946; each brother 1/6 share in cash balance; movables including stock-in-trade divided equally; plaintiff 1/6 share in motor garage, defendants 1 and 2 to pay price.
One brother minor; court accepted compromise as beneficial, passed preliminary decree on July 25, 1947.

Plaintiff commenced fresh suit on February 23, 1949, claiming share of profits and assets of motor business by defendants 1 and 2 after March 31, 1946; alleged compromise made in hurry, omitted future conduct of motor business, still joint family business.
Plaintiff's liquor shop licence expiring April 1, 1946; notice dated December 12, 1945 to brothers intending to run liquor shops exclusively independently post that date.
Plaintiff had Rs. 13,000 cash in hand vs brothers' Rs. 3,000.

Trial court (Civil Judge, Thana, June 30, 1951): suit not barred by res judicata, decision in prior suit not by fraud/misrepresentation/mistake; motor business post-partition not joint but analogous to partnership post-dissolution under s.37 Partnership Act; preliminary decree for accounts from March 31, 1946 to final decree date.

High Court (Bavdekar and Dixit JJ., March 25, 1952): modified decree to accounts till business discontinued; not barred by res judicata or O.II r.2 CPC; different cause of action; under s.90 Indian Trusts Act, liable to account.
Plaintiff filed application November 22, 1947 alleging misapprehension in compromise; abandoned April 6, 1948 to pursue independent suit.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit is barred by res judicata due to the compromise decree in suit No. 39 of 1945.
Whether the suit is barred by Order II rule 2(3) of the Code of Civil Procedure.
Whether defendants Nos. 1 and 2 are liable to account for motor business profits post March 31, 1946 under s.90 Indian Trusts Act or analogous to s.37 Partnership Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cause of action in suit for partition is desire to separate; same in both suits; barred by res judicata and Order II rule 2 CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: res judicata; Order II rule 2 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Compromise made after due deliberation; accounts confined to March 31, 1946; closed door to reopening beyond that date.
Section 90 Indian Trusts Act not applicable.

respondent_arguments.text: Compromise made in hurry; omitted provision for future conduct of motor business post March 31, 1946; motor business still joint family business.

court_reasoning.text: Compromise confined accounts to March 31, 1946 after full consideration, not vitiated by fraud etc.; parties dealt at arms length; binding; plaintiff intended exclusive liquor business post date as per notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Compromise closed door to reopening accounts beyond March 31, 1946.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiff abandoned right to accounts post date; status changed to tenants in common; no oversight as parties knew businesses might continue but did not provide for accounts post date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mention of specific date shows intention to limit accounts.

court_reasoning.text: Compromise decree as binding as contested decree; res judicata applies.
By confining claim to March 31, 1946, plaintiff relinquished subsequent claim; barred by O.II r.2(3) CPC; same cause of action - desire to separate and divide property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Omission to sue for all reliefs without leave bars later suit.

court_reasoning.text: No need to consider Trusts Act s.90 as suit barred.

holdings.text: Compromise decree in prior suit bars reopening accounts of motor business after March 31, 1946 by res judicata.
Claim barred by Order II rule 2(3) CPC as plaintiff omitted to sue for subsequent accounts without leave.
No liability to account post March 31, 1946 as businesses severed per compromise.

statutes_cited.name: Partnership Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Trial court applied by analogy for post-dissolution accounting; not adopted by SC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Trusts Act
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court held defendants liable as co-owners to account for profits; SC held issue does not arise.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Bars suit for omitted relief; applied by SC.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court decree, held suit barred by res judicata and Order II rule 2(3) CPC; no accounts for motor business post March 31, 1946 per binding compromise.

key_quotes.text: the only legitimate conclusion possible is that the parties had agreed to confine the taking of all accounts upto March 31,1946, and had closed the door to reopening them beyond that date.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation of compromise binding parties.

key_quotes.text: a consent decree is as binding upon the parties thereto as a decree passed by invitum.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes res judicata effect of compromise decree.

key_quotes.text: if a person omits, except with the leave of the Court, to sue for all reliefs to which he is entitled, he shall not afterwards sue for any relief so omitted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct application of O.II r.2(3) CPC.
